Description: Fragmentary steatite head and upper body of a young male figure, the lower body and base now lost. The figure is depicted wearing a long braided wig with horizontal striations, set low on the forehead and with the plaited braid falling onto the figure’s back. His large ears protruding slightly forwards. The upper body appears to be bare and there is a notable swelling of the muscle at the chest and a narrowing of the waist. The eyes are wide and with a heavy ridge depicting the upper eyelid, the left side eye now slightly faded. The nose is long and broad at the tip, and the mouth is full with thick lips which are slightly asymmetrical in shape. The face is particularly rounded and fleshy in appearance at the jawline and neck. There are a number of small chips across the statue surface, with slightly larger chips to the right side ear, top of the wig, and damage to the bridge of the nose. The figure is attached to a modern rectangular base.
Curator's comments: Stylistic features such as the oversized ears and the heavy eyelids suggest a date of the Twelfth Dynasty, likely the latter half. The provenance of the figure is uncertain.
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
